==Aftermath==
==Aftermath==
Mancini's victory over Chacon would prove to be the last of his career. Mancini would next face his mandatory challenger [[Livingstone Bramble]] that June, who upset Mancini via 14th-round technical knockout. Bramble would again defeat Mancini in their rematch in February 1985 after which Mancini retired at the age of 24, citing damage to his eyes and a desire to pursue an acting career as reasons.<ref>[https://www.upi.com/Archives/1985/08/23/There-are-days-when-Ray-Boom-Boom-Mancini-wakes/5196493617600/ There are days when Ray 'Boom Boom' Mancini wakes...], UPI article, 1985-08-23, Retrieved on 2026-02-08</ref> He made two one-off returns in 1989 and 1992
Mancini's victory over Chacon would prove to be the last of his career. Mancini would next face his mandatory challenger [[Livingstone Bramble]] that June, who upset Mancini via 14th-round technical knockout. Bramble would again defeat Mancini in their rematch in February 1985 after which Mancini retired at the age of 24, citing damage to his eyes and a desire to pursue an acting career as reasons.<ref>[https://www.upi.com/Archives/1985/08/23/There-are-days-when-Ray-Boom-Boom-Mancini-wakes/5196493617600/ There are days when Ray 'Boom Boom' Mancini wakes...], UPI article, 1985-08-23, Retrieved on 2026-02-08</ref> He made two one-off returns in 1989 and 1992, but lost both fights to [[Héctor Camacho]] and [[Greg Haugen]] respectively.

Line 173: Line 173:
As home secretary, Whitelaw adopted a hard-line approach to law and order. He improved police pay and embarked upon a programme of extensive prison building. His four-year tenure in office, however, was generally perceived as a troubled one. His much vaunted "[[short, sharp shock]]" policy, whereby convicted young offenders were detained in secure units and subjected to quasi-military discipline, won approval from the public but proved expensive to implement.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} He was home secretary during the six-day [[Iranian Embassy siege]] in April–May 1980.
As home secretary, Whitelaw adopted a hard-line approach to law and order. He improved police pay and embarked upon a programme of extensive prison building. His four-year tenure in office, however, was generally perceived as a troubled one. His much vaunted "[[short, sharp shock]]" policy, whereby convicted young offenders were detained in secure units and subjected to quasi-military discipline, won approval from the public but proved expensive to implement.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} He was home secretary during the six-day [[Iranian Embassy siege]] in April–May 1980.


In March 1981, he approved [[Wolverhampton]] Metropolitan Borough Council's 14-day ban on political marches in the borough in response to a planned [[National Front (United Kingdom)|National Front]] demonstration there.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xgdfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4Y0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6565,4462303&dq=wolverhampton+million+unemployment&hl=en |title=New Sunday Times – Google News Archive Search |website=news.google.com}}</ref>
In March 1981, he approved [[Wolverhampton]] Metropolitan Borough Council's 14-day ban on political marches in the borough in response to a planned [[National Front (UK)|National Front]] demonstration there.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xgdfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4Y0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6565,4462303&dq=wolverhampton+million+unemployment&hl=en |title=New Sunday Times – Google News Archive Search |website=news.google.com}}</ref>


[[Inner city]] decay, unemployment and what was perceived at the time as heavy-handed policing of [[ethnic minorities]] (notably the application of what some called the "notorious" [[sus law]]) sparked [[1981 England riots|major riots]] in London, Liverpool, Birmingham and Leeds, and a spate of disturbances elsewhere. The [[Provisional IRA]] escalated its bombing campaign in England.

'''Reginald B. Alcock''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|PC}} (April 16, 1948 – October 14, 2011) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] politician. He represented the riding of [[Winnipeg South]] in the [[House of Commons of Canada]] from 1993 to 2006 and was a [[cabinet minister]] in the government of [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Paul Martin]]. Alcock was a member of the [[Liberal Party of Canada]].
'''Reginald B. Alcock''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|PC}} (April 16, 1948 – October 14, 2011) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] politician. He represented the riding of [[Winnipeg South]] as a [[Member of Parliament (Canada)|Member of Parliament]] (MP) in the [[House of Commons of Canada]] from 1993 to 2006 and was a [[cabinet minister]] in the government of [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Paul Martin]]. Alcock was a member of the [[Liberal Party of Canada]].

'''Wilanów Wysoki''' ({{IPA|pl|viˈla.nuf ˈɲis.ki|lang}}; {{lit|High-rise Wilanów}}) is a [[List of districts and neighbourhoods of Warsaw|neighbourhood]], and a [[List of districts and neighbourhoods of Warsaw|City Information System area]], in [[Warsaw]], Poland, within the [[Wilanów]] district.
'''Wilanów Wysoki''' ({{IPA|pl|viˈla.nuf vɘ̟ˈsɔ.ki|lang}}; {{lit|High-rise Wilanów}}) is a [[List of districts and neighbourhoods of Warsaw|neighbourhood]], and a [[List of districts and neighbourhoods of Warsaw|City Information System area]], in [[Warsaw]], Poland, within the [[Wilanów]] district.




Line 66: Line 66:


== History ==
== History ==
Between 1972 and 1975, the housing estate of Wilanów I was developed with several buildings, placed between Sobieskiego, Nałęczowska, Niemirowska, Resorowa, and Lentza Streets. Designed by T. Mrówczyński, it consisted of mid- and high-rise apartment buildings, constructed using thr [[large panel system building|large panel system]] technique. It had a total of 730 apartments for around 2,200 residents, and covered an area of 5 ha. The area was expanded between 1976 and 1979, with another housing estate, known as Wilanów II, located between Królowej Marysieńki, Lentza, Resorowa, and Goplańska Streets. It was designed by J. Lipińska, it consisted of high-rise apartment buildings, also constructed with the large panel system technique, and covered an area of 20 ha.
Between 1972 and 1975, the housing estate of Wilanów I was developed with several buildings, placed between Sobieskiego, Nałęczowska, Niemirowska, Resorowa, and Lentza Streets. Designed by T. Mrówczyński, it consisted of mid- and high-rise apartment buildings, constructed using the [[large panel system building|large panel system]] technique. It had a total of 730 apartments for around 2,200 residents, and covered an area of 5 ha. The area was expanded between 1976 and 1979, with another housing estate, known as Wilanów II, located between Królowej Marysieńki, Lentza, Resorowa, and Goplańska Streets. It was designed by J. Lipińska, it consisted of high-rise apartment buildings, also constructed with the large panel system technique, and covered an area of 20 ha.<ref name=ew>Barbara Petrozolin-Skowrońska (editor): Encyklopedia Warszawy. Warsaw: Wydawnictwo Naukowe PWN, 1994. ISBN 83-01-08836-2. (in Polish)</ref><ref name=chemil>Lech Chmielewski: Przewodnik warszawski. Gawęda o nowej Warszawie. Warsaw: Agencja Omnipress, Państwowe Przedsiębiorstwo Wydawnicze Rzeczpospolita. ISBN 8385028560. (in Polish)</ref>


In the 1980s, another housing estate, designated as Wilanów III, was built to the south, between Królowej Marysieński Street, Kosiarzy Street, Wilanowska Avenue, and Lentza Street, on an area of 11 ha. It was developed by the [[Council of Ministers (Poland)|Council of Ministers Office]], on an area which was [[Nationalization#Expropriation|expropriated]] for the construction of a hospital in 1975. It consisted of mid- and high-rise apartment buildings, constructed with the large panel system technique, and designed by W. Piziarski, J. Semeniuk, among others architects. Majority of its apparents were assigned to the politicians if the [[Polish United Workers' Party]], including [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]], [[Leszek Miller]], [[Józef Oleksy]], [[Jerzy Szmajdziński]], and [[Janusz Zemke]], among others. The housing estate became colloquially known by the public as the Bay of Red Pigs ({{langx|pl|Zatoka czerwonych świń}}).
In the 1980s, another housing estate, designated as Wilanów III, was built to the south, between Królowej Marysieński Street, Kosiarzy Street, Wilanowska Avenue, and Lentza Street, on an area of 11 ha. It was developed by the [[Council of Ministers (Poland)|Council of Ministers Office]], on an area which was [[Nationalization#Expropriation|expropriated]] for the construction of a hospital in 1975.<ref name=fakt>{{cite web|url=https://www.fakt.pl/polityka/warszawa-osiedle-stworzone-dla-smietanki-pzpr-tak-wyglada-dzisiaj/dlbz7g9|website=fakt.pl|title=Osiedle stworzone dla śmietanki PZPR. Trudno uwierzyć, jak dzisiaj wygląda|author=Robert Fonte Roldan|date=20 November 2025|language=pl}}</ref> It consisted of mid- and high-rise apartment buildings, constructed with the large panel system technique, and designed by W. Piziarski, J. Semeniuk, among others architects.<ref name=ew><ref name=chemil/> Majority of its apparents were assigned to the politicians of the [[Polish United Workers' Party]], including [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]], [[Leszek Miller]], [[Józef Oleksy]], [[Jerzy Szmajdziński]], and [[Janusz Zemke]], among others. The housing estate became colloquially known by the public as the Bay of Red Pigs ({{langx|pl|Zatoka czerwonych świń}}).<ref name=fakt/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wprost.pl/tygodnik/1449/jak-mieszkaja-politycy.html|website=wprost.pl|title=Jak mieszkają politycy|author1=Piotr Kudzia|author2=Grzegorz Pawelczyk|author3=Piotr Gabryel|author4=Michał Gwardyś|language=pl|date=7 May 2000}}</ref>


In 2006, the [[National Public Prosecutor's Office]], from the request by the [[Internal Security Agency]], begun an investigation into the owners of the apartments in buildings at Wiktorii Wiedeńskiej and Marconich Streets, within the housing estate of Wilanów III. They were sold by the city to the residents between 1996 and 1998, with prices greatly lower than their contemporary market value. Among investigated were high-ranking members of the government, including former president Aleksander Kwaśniewski, and former prime ministers Leszek Miller and Józef Oleksy. In 2008, the investigation was [[Nolle prosequi|dismissed]], in 41 cases due to lack of evidence, and in 4, due to the [[Statute of limitations|expiration of the statute of limitation]].
In 2006, the [[National Public Prosecutor's Office]], from the request by the [[Internal Security Agency]], begun an investigation into the owners of the apartments in buildings at Wiktorii Wiedeńskiej and Marconich Streets, within the housing estate of Wilanów III. They were sold by the city to the residents between 1996 and 1998, with prices greatly lower than their contemporary market value. Among investigated were high-ranking members of the government, including former president Aleksander Kwaśniewski, and former prime ministers Leszek Miller and Józef Oleksy. In 2008, the investigation was [[Nolle prosequi|dismissed]], in 41 cases due to lack of evidence, and in 4, due to the [[Statute of limitations|expiration of the statute of limitation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wprost.pl/przeglad-prasy/143809/sledztwo-w-zatoce-swin-umorzone.html|title=Śledztwo w 'zatoce świń' umorzone|date=7 November 2008|language=pl|website=wprost.pl}}</ref>


== Characteristics ==
== Characteristics ==
The neighbourhood of Wilanów Wysoki is a mid- and high-rise residential area, predominantly consisting of apartment buildings constructed in the 1970s and 1980s, using the [[large panel system building|large panel system technique]]. It divided into three housing estates, including Wilanów I, located between
The neighbourhood of Wilanów Wysoki is a mid- and high-rise residential area, predominantly consisting of apartment buildings constructed in the 1970s and 1980s, using the [[large panel system building|large panel system technique]]. It is divided into three housing estates, including Wilanów I, with an area of 5 ha, located between Sobieskiego, Nałęczowska, Niemirowska, Resorowa, and Lentza Street; Wilanów II, with an area of 20 ha, between Królowej Marysieńki, Lentza, Resorowa, and Goplańska Streets; and Wilanów III, with an area of 11 ha, between Królowej Marysieński Street, Kosiarzy Street, Wilanowska Avenue, and Lentza Street.<ref name=ew/><ref name=chmiel/> The later of the three is colloquially known as the Bay of Red Pigs ({{langx|pl|Zatoka czerwonych świń}}), due it it being inhabited by the politicians of the [[Polish United Workers' Party]] in the 1980s.<ref name=fakt/>

== Location and boundaries ==
Wilanów Niski is a City Information System area in Warsaw, located in the central north portion of the [[Wilanów]] district. Its boundaries are approximately determined to the northwest by Nałęczowska Street, Niemirowska Street, and Goplańska Street; to the northeast by Królowej Marysieńki Street and in a streight line from Obornicka Street; to the southeast by Wilanowska Avenue; and to the southwest by Sobieskiego Street. The neighbourhood borders [[Sadyba]] to the north, [[Wilanów Niski]] to the east, [[Powsinek]] and [[Wilanów Królewski]] to the south, and [[Stegny, Warsaw|Stegny]] to the west.<ref name=msi>{{cite web|url=https://zdm.waw.pl/miejski-system-informacji/obszary-msi/dzielnica-wilanow/|website=zdm.waw.pl|title=Dzielnica Wilanów|language=pl}}</ref>

== History ==
== History ==
Between 1972 and 1975, the housing estate of Wilanów I was developed with several buildings, placed between Sobieskiego, Nałęczowska, Niemirowska, Resorowa, and Lentza Streets. Designed by T. Mrówczyński, it consisted of mid- and high-rise apartment buildings, constructed using thr [[large panel system building|large panel system]] technique. It had a total of 730 apartments for around 2,200 residents, and covered an area of 5 ha. The area was expanded between 1976 and 1979, with another housing estate, known as Wilanów II, located between Królowej Marysieńki, Lentza, Resorowa, and Goplańska Streets. It was designed by J. Lipińska, it consisted of high-rise apartment buildings, also constructed with the large panel system technique, and covered an area of 20 ha.
Between 1972 and 1975, the housing estate of Wilanów I was developed with several buildings, placed between Sobieskiego, Nałęczowska, Niemirowska, Resorowa, and Lentza Streets. Designed by T. Mrówczyński, it consisted of mid- and high-rise apartment buildings, constructed using the [[large panel system building|large panel system]] technique. It had a total of 730 apartments for around 2,200 residents, and covered an area of 5 ha. The area was expanded between 1976 and 1979, with another housing estate, known as Wilanów II, located between Królowej Marysieńki, Lentza, Resorowa, and Goplańska Streets. It was designed by J. Lipińska, it consisted of high-rise apartment buildings, also constructed with the large panel system technique, and covered an area of 20 ha.<ref name=ew>Barbara Petrozolin-Skowrońska (editor): Encyklopedia Warszawy. Warsaw: Wydawnictwo Naukowe PWN, 1994. ISBN 83-01-08836-2. (in Polish)</ref><ref name=chemil>Lech Chmielewski: Przewodnik warszawski. Gawęda o nowej Warszawie. Warsaw: Agencja Omnipress, Państwowe Przedsiębiorstwo Wydawnicze Rzeczpospolita. ISBN 8385028560. (in Polish)</ref>


In the 1980s, another housing estate, designated as Wilanów III, was built to the south, between Królowej Marysieński Street, Kosiarzy Street, Wilanowska Avenue, and Lentza Street, on an area of 11 ha. It was developed by the [[Council of Ministers (Poland)|Council of Ministers Office]], on an area which was [[Nationalization#Expropriation|expropriated]] for the construction of a hospital in 1975. It consisted of mid- and high-rise apartment buildings, constructed with the large panel system technique, and designed by W. Piziarski, J. Semeniuk, among others architects. Majority of its apparents were assigned to the politicians if the [[Polish United Workers' Party]], including [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]], [[Leszek Miller]], [[Józef Oleksy]], [[Jerzy Szmajdziński]], and [[Janusz Zemke]], among others. The housing estate became colloquially known by the public as the Bay of Red Pigs ({{langx|pl|Zatoka czerwonych świń}}).
In the 1980s, another housing estate, designated as Wilanów III, was built to the south, between Królowej Marysieński Street, Kosiarzy Street, Wilanowska Avenue, and Lentza Street, on an area of 11 ha. It was developed by the [[Council of Ministers (Poland)|Council of Ministers Office]], on an area which was [[Nationalization#Expropriation|expropriated]] for the construction of a hospital in 1975.<ref name=fakt>{{cite web|url=https://www.fakt.pl/polityka/warszawa-osiedle-stworzone-dla-smietanki-pzpr-tak-wyglada-dzisiaj/dlbz7g9|website=fakt.pl|title=Osiedle stworzone dla śmietanki PZPR. Trudno uwierzyć, jak dzisiaj wygląda|author=Robert Fonte Roldan|date=20 November 2025|language=pl}}</ref> It consisted of mid- and high-rise apartment buildings, constructed with the large panel system technique, and designed by W. Piziarski, J. Semeniuk, among others architects.<ref name=ew><ref name=chemil/> Majority of its apparents were assigned to the politicians of the [[Polish United Workers' Party]], including [[Aleksander Kwaśniewski]], [[Leszek Miller]], [[Józef Oleksy]], [[Jerzy Szmajdziński]], and [[Janusz Zemke]], among others. The housing estate became colloquially known by the public as the Bay of Red Pigs ({{langx|pl|Zatoka czerwonych świń}}).<ref name=fakt/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wprost.pl/tygodnik/1449/jak-mieszkaja-politycy.html|website=wprost.pl|title=Jak mieszkają politycy|author1=Piotr Kudzia|author2=Grzegorz Pawelczyk|author3=Piotr Gabryel|author4=Michał Gwardyś|language=pl|date=7 May 2000}}</ref>


In 2006, the [[National Public Prosecutor's Office]], from the request by the [[Internal Security Agency]], begun an investigation into the owners of the apartments in buildings at Wiktorii Wiedeńskiej and Marconich Streets, within the housing estate of Wilanów III. They were sold by the city to the residents between 1996 and 1998, with prices greatly lower than their contemporary market value. Among investigated were high-ranking members of the government, including former president Aleksander Kwaśniewski, and former prime ministers Leszek Miller and Józef Oleksy. In 2008, the investigation was [[Nolle prosequi|dismissed]], in 41 cases due to lack of evidence, and in 4, due to the [[Statute of limitations|expiration of the statute of limitation]].

== Welcome! ==

Hello, and '''''[[Help:Getting started|welcome]] to Wikipedia!'''''

Thank you for contributing edits that were made in good faith, but have been deemed to not contribute positively to the article, and thus been [[Help:Reverting|reverted]]. You are welcome to discuss it in the article [[WP:TALK|talk page]]. Also, you can experiment with your edits in the [[Wikipedia:Sandbox|sandbox]] or seek advice (see below).

Some good links for newcomers are:
*[[Help:Contents|Help contents]] – the main help page.
*[[Help:Cheatsheet|Quick guide]] – a "cheatsheet" listing the main editing commands.
*[[Wikipedia:Five pillars|The five pillars of Wikipedia]]
*[[Wikipedia:Contributing to Wikipedia|Contributing to Wikipedia]]
*[[Help:Your first article|How to create your first article]]
* [[WP:COI|Avoid conflicts of interest]]
*[[Help:Introduction|Tutorial]]
*[[Wikipedia:Task Center|Task Center]]{{snd}}need some ideas of what kind of things need doing? Go [[Wikipedia:Task Center|here]].

Please [[Wikipedia:Signatures|sign your name]] on talk pages using four tildes (~~~~); this will automatically produce your name and a timestamp. If you need help, check out the [[Wikipedia:Teahouse|Teahouse]], ask the [[Wikipedia:Help desk|Help Desk]], or place <code>{{Help me<nowiki>}}</nowiki></code> on your talk page and someone will show up shortly to answer your questions.

Once again, welcome!<!-- Template:Welcome-suboptimal --> [[User:Augmented Seventh|Augmented Seventh]] ([[User talk:Augmented Seventh|talk]]) 09:57, 8 February 2026 (UTC)

On 1 May, Diaby suffered a severe ankle [[bone fracture|fracture]] after being on the receiving end of a tackle, described by the media as "horrendous", from [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] defender [[Dan Smith (footballer, born 1986)|Dan Smith]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/abou-diaby-shown-great-strength-3369910 |title=Abou Diaby has shown great strength to bounce back from horror injury, says Patrick Vieira|work=Daily Mirror |location=UK |date=14 November 2009 |access-date=3 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/4963628.stm|title=Diaby injury mars Arsenal victory|publisher=[[BBC|BBC Sport]]|date=1 May 2006 |access-date=12 March 2010}}</ref> After the match, Wenger described the tackle as "a bad kick and an unnecessary one" and also criticised his competitors' over-physicality, while interim Sunderland manager [[Kevin Ball]] defended Smith stating "Smith is not a malicious, dirty player and I think it's unfair to make that call on him and say he deliberately went to do it. Dan went for the ball, unfortunately Diaby was quicker than him".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2006/SPORT/football/05/02/england.arsenal/index.html|title=Arsenal unhappy after Diaby injury|publisher=[[CNN|Cable News Network]]|date=2 May 2006 |access-date=3 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=366775&cc=5901|title=Sunderland boss defends Smith in Diaby tackle row|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=3 May 2006|access-date=3 April 2011|archive-date=24 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024144826/http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=366775&cc=5901|url-status=dead}}</ref> As a result of the injury, Diaby missed the [[2006 UEFA Champions League Final]], as well as the [[2006 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]]. He underwent three surgeries to repair the injury and was told by doctors that the injury could possibly be career-ending.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport-old/football/2007/09/24/diaby-s-career-fear-over-ankle-injury-115875-19837106/|title=Diaby's career fear over ankle injury|work=Daily Mirror |location=UK|date=24 September 2007 |access-date=3 April 2011}}</ref> Following the surgeries, he underwent eight months of rehabilitation and made his return to first team action in the [[2006–07 FA Premier League|2006–07 season]] in a League Cup match against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. He appeared as a substitute in the match as Arsenal won 6–3.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/6236687.stm|title=Liverpool 3–6 Arsenal|publisher=[[BBC|BBC Sport]]|date=9 January 2007 |access-date=3 April 2011|first=Sam|last=Lyon}}</ref> On 25 February 2007, while participating in the [[2007 Football League Cup Final]] against Chelsea, Diaby, while attempting to clear the ball out of the Arsenal defense, accidentally kicked rival defender [[John Terry]] in the face. Unconscious, Terry was stretchered off and hospitalized, but recovered to return to the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff for the trophy presentation following Chelsea's 2–1 win.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/chelsea-s-john-terry-can-t-remember-kick-to-head-1.674001 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] | title=Chelsea's John Terry can't remember kick to head | date=26 February 2007}}</ref> Though Arsenal lost, Diaby was credited with an assist on the team's only goal of the match, which was converted by [[Theo Walcott]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/6371613.stm|title=Live – Carling Cup final|publisher=[[BBC|BBC Sport]]|date=25 February 2007 |access-date=3 April 2011}}</ref> Diaby scored his first and only goal of the campaign on 14 March in a 1–0 win over Aston Villa when he deflected in a [[Júlio Baptista]] shot.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sanghera |first1=Mandeep |title=Aston Villa 0-1 Arsenal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/6437189.stm |website=BBC Sport |access-date=6 July 2020 |date=14 March 2007}}</ref> He remained a fixture within the team for the rest of the campaign, mostly as a substitute as he only started in consecutive matches once.
On 1 May, Diaby suffered a severe ankle [[bone fracture|fracture]] after being on the receiving end of a tackle, described by the media as "horrendous", from [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] defender [[Dan Smith (footballer, born 1986)|Dan Smith]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/abou-diaby-shown-great-strength-3369910 |title=Abou Diaby has shown great strength to bounce back from horror injury, says Patrick Vieira|work=Daily Mirror |location=UK |date=14 November 2009 |access-date=3 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/a/arsenal/4963628.stm|title=Diaby injury mars Arsenal victory|publisher=[[BBC|BBC Sport]]|date=1 May 2006 |access-date=12 March 2010}}</ref> After the match, Wenger described the tackle as "a bad kick and an unnecessary one" and also criticised his competitors' over-physicality, while interim Sunderland manager [[Kevin Ball]] defended Smith stating "Smith is not a malicious, dirty player and I think it's unfair to make that call on him and say he deliberately went to do it. Dan went for the ball, unfortunately Diaby was quicker than him".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2006/SPORT/football/05/02/england.arsenal/index.html|title=Arsenal unhappy after Diaby injury|publisher=[[CNN|Cable News Network]]|date=2 May 2006 |access-date=3 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=366775&cc=5901|title=Sunderland boss defends Smith in Diaby tackle row|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=3 May 2006|access-date=3 April 2011|archive-date=24 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024144826/http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=366775&cc=5901|url-status=dead}}</ref> As a result of the injury, Diaby missed the [[2006 UEFA Champions League Final]], as well as the [[2006 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]]. He underwent three surgeries to repair the injury and was told by doctors that the injury could possibly be career-ending.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport-old/football/2007/09/24/diaby-s-career-fear-over-ankle-injury-115875-19837106/|title=Diaby's career fear over ankle injury|work=Daily Mirror |location=UK|date=24 September 2007 |access-date=3 April 2011}}</ref> Following the surgeries, he underwent eight months of rehabilitation and made his return to first team action in the [[2006–07 FA Premier League|2006–07 season]] in a League Cup match against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. He appeared as a substitute in the match as Arsenal won 6–3.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/6236687.stm|title=Liverpool 3–6 Arsenal|publisher=[[BBC|BBC Sport]]|date=9 January 2007 |access-date=3 April 2011|first=Sam|last=Lyon}}</ref> On 25 February 2007, while participating in the [[2007 Football League Cup Final]] against Chelsea, Diaby, while attempting to clear the ball out of the Arsenal defense, accidentally kicked rival defender [[John Terry]] in the face. Unconscious, Terry was stretchered off and hospitalized, but recovered to return to the Millennium Stadium in Cardiff for the trophy presentation following Chelsea's 2–1 win.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/chelsea-s-john-terry-can-t-remember-kick-to-head-1.674001 |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] | title=Chelsea's John Terry can't remember kick to head | date=26 February 2007}}</ref> Though Arsenal lost, Diaby was credited with an assist on the team's only goal of the match, which was converted by [[Theo Walcott]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/6371613.stm|title=Live – Carling Cup final|publisher=[[BBC|BBC Sport]]|date=25 February 2007 |access-date=3 April 2011}}</ref> Diaby scored his first and only goal of the campaign on 14 March in a 1–0 win over Aston Villa when he deflected in a [[Júlio Baptista]] shot.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sanghera |first1=Mandeep |title=Aston Villa 0-1 Arsenal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/6437189.stm |website=BBC Sport |access-date=6 July 2020 |date=14 March 2007}}</ref> He remained a fixture within the team for the rest of the campaign, mostly as a substitute as he only started in consecutive matches once.


In Diaby's [[2007–08 Arsenal F.C. season|first full season with Arsenal]], he scored his first goal on 22 September 2007 in the club's 5–0 win over [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport-old/football/2007/09/23/arsenal-5-0-derby-115875-19833124/ | title = Arsenal 5–0 Derby |work=Daily Mirror |location=UK | first = Anthony | last = Clavane | date = 23 September 2007 | access-date =3 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/en/report/219294/report.html?soccernet=true |title=Arsenal 5–0 Derby: Hat-trick hero Adebayor |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=22 September 2007 |access-date=10 March 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140417220210/http://espnfc.com/en/report/219294/report.html?soccernet=true |archive-date=17 April 2014}}</ref> Three days later, he assisted on a goal in a 2–0 League Cup win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{Cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/sep/26/match.arsenal | title = Bendtner header breaks deadlock | date = 25 September 2007 | access-date =3 April 2011 | location=London |work=The Guardian | first=Rob | last=Smyth}}</ref> In December 2007, Diaby scored goals in back-to-back matches for the first time in his career. He scored the first goal on 12 December in the team's final Champions League group stage match against [[Romania]]n club [[FC Steaua București|Steaua București]]. Arsenal won the match 2–1.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season=2008/round=15105/match=301245/index.html |title=Arsenal hold off Steaua recovery |publisher=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=12 December 2007 |access-date=3 April 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114102721/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season%3D2008/round%3D15105/match%3D301245/index.html |archive-date=14 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/7134129.stm|title=Arsenal 2–1 Steaua Bucharest|publisher=BBC |date=12 December 2007 |access-date=2 September 2009|first=Chris|last=Bevan}}</ref> Six days later, Diaby scored Arsenal's opening goal in the club's 3–2 away win over [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/7145781.stm | work=[[BBC|BBC Sport]] | title=Blackburn 2–3 Arsenal (aet) | date=18 December 2007 | access-date =3 April 2011 | first=Chris | last=Whyatt}}</ref> Diaby failed to chart anything statistical for the rest of the winter months aside from an assist in a 4–1 win over Everton. On 29 March 2008, Diaby was sent off for the first time in his professional career in a league match against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] for a studs-up tackle on defender [[Grétar Steinsson]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/7309362.stm | work=[[BBC|BBC Sport]]| title=Bolton 2–3 Arsenal | date=29 March 2008 | access-date =3 December 2010 | first = Ian | last = Hughes}}</ref> Diaby was defended by Wenger who stated "I don't think Diaby's tackle was malicious, it was more protective". Wenger also stated that Diaby's tackle should not be compared to [[Eduardo da Silva#Leg injury|what had happened to teammate Eduardo da Silva a few weeks earlier]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/article3649049.ece |work=The Times |location=UK| title=Arsene Wenger leaps to defence of Abou Diaby| date=31 March 2008 | access-date =3 April 2011 | first=Kaveh | last=Solhekol}}{{dead link|date=September 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Wenger was, subsequently, criticized by the English media for [[Flip-flop (politics)|flip-flopping]] on the subject due to providing differing statements when Arsenal players are on the receiving end of tackles and when they are the aggressors.{{citation needed|date=July 2020}}
In Diaby's [[2007–08 Arsenal F.C. season|first full season with Arsenal]], he scored his first goal on 22 September 2007 in the club's 5–0 win over [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport-old/football/2007/09/23/arsenal-5-0-derby-115875-19833124/ | title = Arsenal 5–0 Derby |work=Daily Mirror |location=UK | first = Anthony | last = Clavane | date = 23 September 2007 | access-date =3 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/en/report/219294/report.html?soccernet=true |title=Arsenal 5–0 Derby: Hat-trick hero Adebayor |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=22 September 2007 |access-date=10 March 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140417220210/http://espnfc.com/en/report/219294/report.html?soccernet=true |archive-date=17 April 2014}}</ref> Three days later, he assisted on a goal in a 2–0 League Cup win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{Cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/sep/26/match.arsenal | title = Bendtner header breaks deadlock | date = 25 September 2007 | access-date =3 April 2011 | location=London |work=The Guardian | first=Rob | last=Smyth}}</ref> In December 2007, Diaby scored goals in back-to-back matches for the first time in his career. He scored the first goal on 12 December in the team's final Champions League group stage match against [[Romania]]n club [[FC Steaua București|Steaua București]]. Arsenal won the match 2–1.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season=2008/round=15105/match=301245/index.html |title=Arsenal hold off Steaua recovery |publisher=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=12 December 2007 |access-date=3 April 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114102721/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season%3D2008/round%3D15105/match%3D301245/index.html |archive-date=14 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/7134129.stm|title=Arsenal 2–1 Steaua Bucharest|publisher=BBC |date=12 December 2007 |access-date=2 September 2009|first=Chris|last=Bevan}}</ref> Six days later, Diaby scored Arsenal's opening goal in the club's 3–2 away win over [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/7145781.stm | work=[[BBC|BBC Sport]] | title=Blackburn 2–3 Arsenal (aet) | date=18 December 2007 | access-date =3 April 2011 | first=Chris | last=Whyatt}}</ref> Diaby failed to chart anything statistical for the rest of the winter months aside from an assist in a 4–1 win over Everton. On 29 March 2008, Diaby was sent off for the first time in his professional career in a league match against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] for a studs-up tackle on defender [[Grétar Steinsson]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/7309362.stm | work=[[BBC|BBC Sport]]| title=Bolton 2–3 Arsenal | date=29 March 2008 | access-date =3 December 2010 | first = Ian | last = Hughes}}</ref> Diaby was defended by Wenger who stated "I don't think Diaby's tackle was malicious, it was more protective". Wenger also stated that Diaby's tackle should not be compared to [[Eduardo da Silva#Leg injury|what had happened to teammate Eduardo da Silva a few weeks earlier]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/article3649049.ece |work=The Times |location=UK| title=Arsene Wenger leaps to defence of Abou Diaby| date=31 March 2008 | access-date =3 April 2011 | first=Kaveh | last=Solhekol}}{{dead link|date=September 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>


After serving his red card suspension, Diaby featured in only one match in the final two months of the season. The match was the second leg of the club's quarter-final Champions League tie against Liverpool. In the match, Diaby netted the opening goal to give Arsenal, who drew 1–1 in the first leg, a 2–1 advantage. Arsenal, however, conceded four goals from Liverpool and lost the tie 5–3 on aggregate.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season=2008/round=15107/match=301910/report=rp.html |title=Reds edge Arsenal in six-goal thriller |publisher=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=8 April 2008 |access-date=3 April 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206081028/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/history/season%3D2008/round%3D15107/match%3D301910/report%3Drp.html |archive-date=6 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/7332209.stm|title=Liverpool 4–2 Arsenal (agg 5–3)|publisher=[[BBC|BBC Sport]]|date=8 April 2008 |access-date=2 September 2009|first=Andrew|last=McKenzie}}</ref> Following the match against Liverpool, Diaby began struggling with a [[thigh]] injury. After the injury relapsed in a reserve match in late April, Diaby was ruled out for the rest of the season.<ref>{{Cite web |last=UEFA.com |title=The official website for European football |url=https://www.uefa.com/errors/ |access-date=2025-02-09 |website=[[UEFA]] |language=en}}</ref>

'''Operation Anger''' (sometimes known as '''Operation Quick Anger''') was a military operation to seize the city of [[Arnhem]] in April 1945, during the closing stages of the [[World War II|Second World War]]. It is also known as the '''Second Battle of Arnhem''' or the '''Liberation of Arnhem'''. The operation was part of the [[First Canadian Army|Canadian First Army's]] liberation of the [[Netherlands]] and was led by the [[49th (West Riding) Infantry Division|49th British Infantry Division]], supported by [[Armoured fighting vehicle|armour]] of the [[5th Canadian Division|5th Canadian Armoured Division]], [[Royal Air Force]] air strikes and boats of the [[Royal Navy]].
'''Operation Anger''' (sometimes mistakenly referred to as '''Operation Quick Anger''') was a military operation to seize the city of [[Arnhem]] in April 1945, during the closing stages of the [[World War II|Second World War]]. It is also known as the '''Second Battle of Arnhem''' or the '''Liberation of Arnhem'''. The operation was part of the [[First Canadian Army |Canadian First Army's]] liberation of the [[Netherlands]] and was led by the [[49th (West Riding) Infantry Division|49th British Infantry Division]], supported by [[Armoured fighting vehicle |armour]] of the [[5th Canadian Division|5th Canadian Armoured Division]], [[Royal Air Force]] air strikes and boats of the [[Royal Navy]].


The [[Allies of World War II|Western Allies]] first [[Battle of Arnhem|tried to liberate Arnhem]] in September 1944 during [[Operation Market Garden]]. Poor planning, the unexpected presence of German armoured units and a delayed advance by ground forces resulted in the British [[1st Airborne Division (United Kingdom)|1st Airborne Division]] being defeated and a new front stabilising south of the city. Fresh planning to take Arnhem began in the new year as the Canadian First Army sought ways to link up its units advancing into the Netherlands. However it was not until April that the liberation of the city became a distinct possibility. After [[II Canadian Corps]] secured the eastern bank of the [[IJssel|IJssel river]] and advanced north, [[I Canadian Corps]] prepared to assault Arnhem.
The [[Allies of World War II|Western Allies]] first [[Battle of Arnhem| tried to liberate Arnhem]] in September 1944 during [[Operation Market Garden]]. Poor planning, the unexpected presence of German armoured units and a delayed advance by ground forces resulted in the British [[1st Airborne Division (United Kingdom)|1st Airborne Division]] being defeated and a new front stabilising south of the city. Fresh planning to take Arnhem began in the new year as the Canadian First Army sought ways to link up its units advancing into the Netherlands. However it was not until April that the liberation of the city became a distinct possibility. After [[II Canadian Corps]] secured the eastern bank of the [[IJssel|IJssel river]] and advanced north, [[I Canadian Corps]] prepared to assault Arnhem.


The operation began on 12 April 1945 and proceeded to plan, as the three infantry brigades of the 49th Division [[Leapfrogging (infantry)|leapfrogged]] each other through the city. Within four days Arnhem was totally under Allied control, allowing the Canadians to advance further into the Netherlands. Less than two weeks after the battle a general [[truce]] brought major combat operations in the country to an end and on 5 May the German commander in chief in the Netherlands surrendered to the Canadian Army. Three days later [[German Instrument of Surrender|Germany unconditionally surrendered]], bringing the war in Europe to a close.

'''Kallang MRT station''' is an [[Elevated railway|above-ground]] [[Mass Rapid Transit (Singapore)|Mass Rapid Transit]] (MRT) station on the [[East–West Line (Singapore)|East–West Line]] (EWL) in [[Kallang]], Singapore. Operated by [[SMRT Trains]], the station primarily serves the [[Kallang]] area as well as [[List of bus stations in Singapore#Lorong 1 Geylang Bus Terminal|Lorong 1 Geylang bus terminal]]. Like many stations in the eastern portion of the EWL, it has a domed roof. It is mostly wheelchair accessible and has bicycle facilities.
'''Kallang MRT station''' is an elevated [[Mass Rapid Transit (Singapore)|Mass Rapid Transit]] (MRT) station on the [[East–West Line (Singapore)|East–West Line]] (EWL) in [[Kallang]], Singapore. Operated by [[SMRT Trains]], the station primarily serves the [[Kallang]] area as well as [[List of bus stations in Singapore#Lorong 1 Geylang Bus Terminal|Lorong 1 Geylang bus terminal]]. Like many stations in the eastern portion of the EWL, it has a dome-shaped segmented roof. It is mostly wheelchair accessible and has bicycle facilities.


First announced in May 1982 as '''Geylang''', it was to be constructed as part of Phase II of the MRT system. Its name was later changed in October 1983. Kallang station commenced operations on 4 November 1989 along with other stations on the eastern stretch of the line. In December 2005, a man jumped in front of an oncoming train and was killed. Half-height [[platform screen doors]] were installed at the station in 2012, along with [[high-volume low-speed fan]]s that following year.  
First announced in May 1982 as '''Geylang''', it was to be constructed as part of Phase II of the MRT system. Its name was later changed in October 1983. Kallang station commenced operations on 4 November 1989 along with other stations on the eastern stretch of the line. Half-height [[platform screen doors]] were installed at the station in 2012, along with [[high-volume low-speed fan]]s that following year.  


==History==
==History==

=== Safety ===
=== Safety ===
On 16 August 1997, a 48-year-old [[Caucasian race|Caucasian]]-[[Singaporeans|Singaporean]] man died after jumping into the path of an oncoming train, which ran him over.<ref>{{Cite news |date=19 August 1997 |title=Man run over by train at Kallang station |url=https://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/digitised/article/straitstimes19970819-1.2.40.5?qt=%22kallang%20station%22,%20mrt&q=%22kallang%20station%22%22mrt%22 |access-date=18 April 2025 |work=[[The Straits Times]] |pages=29}}</ref> On 28 December 2005, a 32-year-old [[Non-resident Indian and Person of Indian Origin|Indian]] man died within minutes after he fell onto the tracks and was subsequently hit by an oncoming west-bound train, causing a temporary disruption for west-bound trains. The man is believed to have [[suicide|jumped to his death]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Yin |first=Jasmine |date=29 December 2005 |title=Train services hit after man's death |url=https://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/digitised/page/today20051229-1.1.4 |url-access= |access-date=20 April 2025 |publisher=TODAY Newspaper |pages=4}}</ref> Following a rise in track intrusions as well as commuters slipping when rushing for the train, the LTA and [[SMRT Trains|SMRT]] decided to install platform screen doors.<ref>{{cite web |author=Wong, Siew Ying |date=26 January 2008 |title=Above-ground MRT stations to have platform screen doors by 2012 |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/324989/1/.html |url-status=dead [[Bill Clinton]], the 42nd [[president of the United States]], developed a social and professional relationship with financier and child sex offender [[Jeffrey Epstein]] that began in the early 1990s and continued into the early 2000s. During [[Clinton's presidency]], Epstein made multiple visits to the [[White House]] and maintained ties with Clinton's associates; after Clinton left office, he traveled on Epstein's private jet on several occasions for charitable trips.<ref name="The Independent-2025">{{Cite web |date=2025-08-06 |title=Bill Clinton and Jeffrey Epstein's friendship timeline |url=https://www.the-independent.com/news/world/americas/us-politics/bill-clinton-jeffrey-epstein-timeline-b2802828.html |access-date=2025-08-13 |website=The Independent |language=en}}</ref> Epstein's interactions with Clinton can be traced to the early 1990s, and concluded in 2003.

'''Zwier Albertus "Alby" Mangels''' (born 16 November 1948) is an Australian adventurer and documentary film-maker widely remembered for his ''World Safari'' adventure travel films (''[[World Safari]]'', ''[[World Safari II]]'', and ''[[World Safari III]]'').<ref name=wild />
⚫
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}}
⚫
'''Zwier Albertus "Alby" Mangels''' (born 16 November 1948) is an Australian adventurer and documentary film-maker widely remembered for his ''World Safari'' adventure travel films (''[[World Safari]]'', ''[[World Safari II]]'', and ''[[World Safari III]]'').<ref name="wild"/>


==Early life and education ==
==Early life and education ==

Zwier Albertus Mangels was born in the Netherlands on 16 November 1948.<ref name=bio/> His father Johannes (Jos) was a leather tanner. The family moved to Australia in 1955, where they settled in [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]].{{cn|date=February 2026}}
After about eighteen months in Australia his parents separated.<ref name="bio" /> His mother Adrianna (Sjann) remarried but died when he was fifteen. He left school at fourteen.<ref name="Epic" />
Zwier Albertus Mangels was born in the Netherlands on 16 November 1948.<ref name=bio/> His father Johannes (Jos) was a leather tanner. The family moved to Australia in 1955, where they settled in [[Mount Burr]], [[South Australia]].<ref name=ABC2026>{{cite news |last1=HASSALL |first1=Greg |title=In rare interview, World Safari documentary-maker Alby Mangels reveals why he 'disappeared' |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-08/why-world-safari-filmmaker-alby-mangels-disappeared/106093710 |access-date=8 February 2026 |work=ABC News (Australia) |date=8 February 2026}}</ref> After about eighteen months in Australia his parents separated.<ref name="bio" /><ref name=ABC2026/> His mother Adrianna (Sjann) remarried but died when he was fifteen. He left school at fourteen.<ref name="Epic" />


As a teenager, he undertook a wide variety of professions, including chicken farming and house construction.<ref name="Epic" />
As a teenager, he undertook a wide variety of professions, including chicken farming and house construction.<ref name="Epic" />


== Travel and filming ==
== Travel and filming ==
⚫
Mangels set off in 1971 with friend John Fields on what was supposed to be a one-off trip. It turned into a six-year odyssey which they filmed through several continents. The resulting film, first shown in Australia in 1977, was a significant success. Mangels continued to travel through the 1980s, filming all the way. Two more World Safari films were made from this subsequent material.<ref name="wild" />


⚫
Mangels set off in 1971 with friend John Fields on what was supposed to be a one-off trip. It turned into a six-year odyssey which they filmed through several continents. The resulting film, first shown in Australia in 1977, was a significant success. Mangels continued to travel through the 1980s, filming all the way. Two more World Safari films were made from this subsequent material.<ref name=wild />
⚫
In April 1983, early colleague Judy Green was involved in an accident with a bus in Brazil and suffered serious head injuries. Formerly part of the Australian ''[[Sale Of The Century]]'' cast, she left Mangels' team to regain the ability to walk.

<ref name="wild">{{cite news |title=The Week |work=Canberra Times |date=12 January 1985 |page=2 |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/122477790}}</ref>
⚫
In April 1983, early colleague Judy Green was involved in an accident with a bus in Brazil and suffered serious head injuries. Formerly part of the Australian ''[[Sale Of The Century]]'' cast, she left Mangels' team to regain the ability to walk.<ref>{{cite news |title=Safari to disaster |work=Canberra Times |date=12 January 1985 |page=2 |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/122477790}}</ref>


==Biographies==
==Biographies==

A companion book to the films, ''Alby Mangels' World Safari'', was published in the 1980s.{{cn|date=February 2026}}
A companion book to the films, ''Alby Mangels' World Safari'', was published in the 1980s.{{cn|date=February 2026}}


Lynn Santer authored Mangels's authorised biography ''Beyond World Safari'' in 2007.<ref name=bio>{{cite book| last=Santer| first=Lynn| title=The Alby Mangels Story: Beyond World Safari| year=2007| publisher=JoJo Publishing| location=Docklands, Victoria| isbn=978-0-9803547-5-1| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2O_RGAAACAAJ| accessdate=30 July 2013}}</ref>

After about eighteen months in Australia his parents separated.<ref name="bio" /> His mother Adrianna (Sjann) remarried but died when he was fifteen. He left school at fourteen.<ref name="Epic" />
Zwier Albertus Mangels was born in the Netherlands on 16 November 1948.<ref name=bio/> His father Johannes (Jos) was a leather tanner. The family moved to Australia in 1955, where they settled in [[Mount Burr]], [[South Australia]].<ref name=ABC2026>{{cite news |last1=HASSALL |first1=Greg |title=In rare interview, World Safari documentary-maker Alby Mangels reveals why he 'disappeared' |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-08/why-world-safari-filmmaker-alby-mangels-disappeared/106093710 |access-date=8 February 2026 |work=ABC News (Australia) |date=8 February 2026}}</ref> After about eighteen months in Australia his parents separated.<ref name="bio" /><ref name=ABC2026/> His mother Adrianna (Sjann) remarried but died when he was fifteen. He left school at fourteen.<ref name="Epic" />


As a teenager, he undertook a wide variety of professions, including chicken farming and house construction.<ref name="Epic" />
As a teenager, he undertook a wide variety of professions, including chicken farming and house construction.<ref name="Epic" />


== Travel and filming ==
== Travel and filming ==
⚫
Mangels set off in 1971 with friend John Fields on what was supposed to be a one-off trip. It turned into a six-year odyssey which they filmed through several continents. The resulting film, first shown in Australia in 1977, was a significant success. Mangels continued to travel through the 1980s, filming all the way. Two more World Safari films were made from this subsequent material.<ref name="wild" />

'''Zwier Albertus "Alby" Mangels''' (born 16 November 1948) is an Australian adventurer and documentary film-maker widely remembered for his ''World Safari'' adventure travel films (''[[World Safari]]'', ''[[World Safari II]]'', and ''[[World Safari III]]'').<ref name="wild"/>


==Early life and education ==
==Early life and education ==

Zwier Albertus Mangels was born in the Netherlands on 16 November 1948.<ref name=bio/> His father Johannes (Jos) was a leather tanner. The family moved to Australia in 1955, where they settled in [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]].{{cn|date=February 2026}}
After about eighteen months in Australia his parents separated.<ref name="bio" /> His mother Adrianna (Sjann) remarried but died when he was fifteen. He left school at fourteen.<ref name="Epic" />
Zwier Albertus Mangels was born in the Netherlands on 16 November 1948.<ref name=bio/> His father Johannes (Jos) was a leather tanner. The family moved to Australia in 1955, where they settled in [[Mount Burr]], [[South Australia]].<ref name=ABC2026>{{cite news |last1=HASSALL |first1=Greg |title=In rare interview, World Safari documentary-maker Alby Mangels reveals why he 'disappeared' |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-08/why-world-safari-filmmaker-alby-mangels-disappeared/106093710 |access-date=8 February 2026 |work=ABC News (Australia) |date=8 February 2026}}</ref> After about eighteen months in Australia his parents separated.<ref name="bio" /><ref name=ABC2026/> His mother Adrianna (Sjann) remarried but died when he was fifteen. He left school at fourteen.<ref name="Epic" />


As a teenager, he undertook a wide variety of professions, including chicken farming and house construction.<ref name="Epic" />
As a teenager, he undertook a wide variety of professions, including chicken farming and house construction.<ref name="Epic" />


== Travel and filming ==
== Travel and filming ==
⚫
Mangels set off in 1971 with friend John Fields on what was supposed to be a one-off trip. It turned into a six-year odyssey which they filmed through several continents. The resulting film, first shown in Australia in 1977, was a significant success. Mangels continued to travel through the 1980s, filming all the way. Two more World Safari films were made from this subsequent material.<ref name="wild" />


⚫
Mangels set off in 1971 with friend John Fields on what was supposed to be a one-off trip. It turned into a six-year odyssey which they filmed through several continents. The resulting film, first shown in Australia in 1977, was a significant success. Mangels continued to travel through the 1980s, filming all the way. Two more World Safari films were made from this subsequent material.<ref name=wild />
⚫
In April 1983, early colleague Judy Green was involved in an accident with a bus in Brazil and suffered serious head injuries. Formerly part of the Australian ''[[Sale Of The Century]]'' cast, she left Mangels' team to regain the ability to walk.

<ref name="wild">{{cite news |title=The Week |work=Canberra Times |date=12 January 1985 |page=2 |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/122477790}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}}
⚫
'''Zwier Albertus "Alby" Mangels''' (born 16 November 1948) is an Australian adventurer and documentary film-maker widely remembered for his ''World Safari'' adventure travel films (''[[World Safari]]'', ''[[World Safari II]]'', and ''[[World Safari III]]'').<ref name=wild />
⚫
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}}
⚫
'''Zwier Albertus "Alby" Mangels''' (born 16 November 1948) is an Australian adventurer and documentary film-maker widely remembered for his ''World Safari'' adventure travel films (''[[World Safari]]'', ''[[World Safari II]]'', and ''[[World Safari III]]'').<ref name="wild"/>


==Early life and education ==
==Early life and education ==

Zwier Albertus Mangels was born in the Netherlands on 16 November 1948.<ref name=bio/> His father Johannes (Jos) was a leather tanner. The family moved to Australia in 1955, where they settled in [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]].{{cn|date=February 2026}}
After about eighteen months in Australia his parents separated.<ref name="bio" /> His mother Adrianna (Sjann) remarried but died when he was fifteen. He left school at fourteen.<ref name="Epic" />
Zwier Albertus Mangels was born in the Netherlands on 16 November 1948.<ref name=bio/> His father Johannes (Jos) was a leather tanner. The family moved to Australia in 1955, where they settled in [[Mount Burr]], [[South Australia]].<ref name=ABC2026>{{cite news |last1=HASSALL |first1=Greg |title=In rare interview, World Safari documentary-maker Alby Mangels reveals why he 'disappeared' |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2026-02-08/why-world-safari-filmmaker-alby-mangels-disappeared/106093710 |access-date=8 February 2026 |work=ABC News (Australia) |date=8 February 2026}}</ref> After about eighteen months in Australia his parents separated.<ref name="bio" /><ref name=ABC2026/> His mother Adrianna (Sjann) remarried but died when he was fifteen. He left school at fourteen.<ref name="Epic" />


As a teenager, he undertook a wide variety of professions, including chicken farming and house construction.<ref name="Epic" />
As a teenager, he undertook a wide variety of professions, including chicken farming and house construction.<ref name="Epic" />


== Travel and filming ==
== Travel and filming ==
⚫
Mangels set off in 1971 with friend John Fields on what was supposed to be a one-off trip. It turned into a six-year odyssey which they filmed through several continents. The resulting film, first shown in Australia in 1977, was a significant success. Mangels continued to travel through the 1980s, filming all the way. Two more World Safari films were made from this subsequent material.<ref name="wild" />


⚫
Mangels set off in 1971 with friend John Fields on what was supposed to be a one-off trip. It turned into a six-year odyssey which they filmed through several continents. The resulting film, first shown in Australia in 1977, was a significant success. Mangels continued to travel through the 1980s, filming all the way. Two more World Safari films were made from this subsequent material.<ref name=wild />
⚫
In April 1983, early colleague Judy Green was involved in an accident with a bus in Brazil and suffered serious head injuries. Formerly part of the Australian ''[[Sale Of The Century]]'' cast, she left Mangels' team to regain the ability to walk.

<ref name="wild">{{cite news |title=The Week |work=Canberra Times |date=12 January 1985 |page=2 |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/122477790}}</ref>
⚫
In April 1983, early colleague Judy Green was involved in an accident with a bus in Brazil and suffered serious head injuries. Formerly part of the Australian ''[[Sale Of The Century]]'' cast, she left Mangels' team to regain the ability to walk.<ref>{{cite news |title=Safari to disaster |work=Canberra Times |date=12 January 1985 |page=2 |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/122477790}}</ref>


==Biographies==
==Biographies==

A companion book to the films, ''Alby Mangels' World Safari'', was published in the 1980s.{{cn|date=February 2026}}
A companion book to the films, ''Alby Mangels' World Safari'', was published in the 1980s.{{cn|date=February 2026}}


Lynn Santer authored Mangels's authorised biography ''Beyond World Safari'' in 2007.<ref name=bio>{{cite book| last=Santer| first=Lynn| title=The Alby Mangels Story: Beyond World Safari| year=2007| publisher=JoJo Publishing| location=Docklands, Victoria| isbn=978-0-9803547-5-1| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2O_RGAAACAAJ| accessdate=30 July 2013}}</ref>
